zuul.d/jobs.yaml.message:
Could you explain what the intention is here? I might be misunderstanding the Zuul documentation, but it appears this is essentially no-op because this job does not have a parent job.

https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/reference/job_def.html#attr-job.secrets.pass-to-parent

> Could you explain what the intention is here? I might be
 > misunderstanding the Zuul documentation, but it appears this is
 > essentially no-op because this job does not have a parent job.
 > 
 > https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/reference/job_def.html#attr-job.secrets.pass-to-parent

Thanks. Yes it is not required here to cascade as we dont have any parent. Looking at the zuul error carefully, i got that the way we are accessing the change_url has issue.

change_url is available at zuul level, so we can directly read it from zuul instead of its sub element.

Also if we have to read from sublement, i assume the ansible syntax would be zuul.items.0.change_url and not items[0]. So looks like it is a syntax issue

swift/common/db.py.message: I guess this part is fairly slow - we're bringing EVERY deleted row into python to evaluate it

What about including the `created_at < ?` in the query? I suppose part of the point of the bug is that we don't *want* to go too quickly -- but if our goal is a slower replicator, I think I'd much prefer an explicit sleep() so we're not wasting CPU cycles.

So this is A LOT closer to the behavior we want, but after seeing https://review.opendev.org/#/c/727876/ fail and thinking about how sqlite locking is going to work I'm worried that as soon as this block fires (i.e. we have a row to delete) we'll pickup a write lock for this connection and the remainder of the (now much slower) _reclaim method with block other writers (like a .pending flush)
Can we do something with more-explicit transactions to convince SQLite to release the write lock in between?
I guess this really has the same problem as the original DELETE query, it's just holding a shared lock during the entire table scan instead of a reserved lock

tripleoclient/utils.py.message: py27:  YAMLLoadWarning: calling yaml.load() without Loader=... is deprecated, as the default Loader is unsafe. Please read https://msg.pyyaml.org/load for full details.
py36:  YAMLLoadWarning: calling yaml.load() without Loader=... is deprecated, as the default Loader is unsafe. Please read https://msg.pyyaml.org/load for full details.
py37:  YAMLLoadWarning: calling yaml.load() without Loader=... is deprecated, as the default Loader is unsafe. Please read https://msg.pyyaml.org/load for full details.

It would be nice if this could support IPv6 too. At the moment it won't because it concatenates them into one big address:

In [29]: v6='2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334'

In [30]: v62='2001:db8::8a2e:370:7334'

In [31]: ':'.join(re.split(',| |:', ','.join([v6, v62])))
Out[31]: '2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334:2001:db8::8a2e:370:7334'

In [32]: 

As per the manual [1]

"You can use either a comma (,) or a colon (:) to separate a list of hosts. The comma is preferred when dealing with ranges and IPv6 addresses."

So if we're more strict and don't support colons, then it will work for v6:

In [33]: ','.join(re.split(',', ','.join([v6, v62])))
Out[33]: '2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334,2001:db8::8a2e:370:7334'

In [34]: 

What do you think about adding a check that if it's an IPv6 address, then you take the stricter comma-only option (and give an error message back if that v6 was passed without comma delimits) but otherwise have the code take the path that you have? 

[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/intro_patterns.html

> The `ansible-playbook --limit` argument only applies to the
 > "inventory_hostname" variable not the "ansible_host" variable.

I was not aware of that. I thought it applied to IPs too and that's why the manual mentioned that is the preferred way when dealing with IPv6 addresses. There is no specific Storage usecase for IPs. If you're confident we won't be using IPs here then, I'm fine with it. Just wanted to point out a potential issues based on my understanding which could be wrong. Let's drop the concern then.

The `ansible-playbook --limit` argument only applies to the "inventory_hostname" variable not the "ansible_host" variable. That means that it cannot limit based on IP addressing information. The host in the inventory would have to be defined with the IPv4 or IPv6 address as the name. I checked a lab environment I have up for Train and none of my hosts are listed with their IP address (they are instead controller0, compute0, etc.). Is there a situation (perhaps with storage) where it would use an IP address instead?

nova/virt/libvirt/blockinfo.py.message: If you end up following my approach on the next file, this can probably be removed

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
This could be SCSI regardless of hw_cdrom_bus being set for AArch64 right?

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/31aa4a6d7f0b8c301b093ad176ee2b44b5d3cec8/nova/virt/libvirt/blockinfo.py#L262-L272
Done
Can you LOG these (maybe max(ret) instead?) in a single DEBUG line?
Aha, sorry I leave a message here for person debug, forget to remove it. Already removed.

Couldn't we update this to only look for type='drive'?

That would list disks and cdroms right?
Actually no, we only want to optionally do this when we know the cdrom is on the SCSI bus. Apologies.
OK, thanks
Can you move this into a util method within blockinfo?
Done
Remove this, otherwise we only end up returning the units used by cdroms.
Done

nit: don't need to wrap this, right?

  disk_info['unit'] = self._get_scsi_controller_max_unit(
      guest, instance.image_meta,
  ) + 1
Thanks, done

It's also possible to configure CD-ROMs to use SCSI via the 'hw_cdrom_bus' image metadata property. Configured on x86_64 host, I see:

    <disk type='file' device='cdrom'>
      <driver name='qemu' type='raw' cache='none'/>
      <source file='/opt/stack/data/nova/instances/4462d350-6f19-442f-9e99-9cbfa00a5cb8/disk.config'/>
      <backingStore/>
      <target dev='sda' bus='scsi'/>
      <readonly/>
      <alias name='scsi0-0-0'/>
      <address type='drive' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'/>
    </disk>

As such, any reason we need to limit this to non-x86 guests? Could we remove this check and instead replace the xpath on line 1410 with something like this?

  ./devices/disk[target[@bus='scsi']]/address[@type='drive']

i.e. fetch all disk devices using a SCSI bus, regardless of their type.

(note: I don't know if the last "[@type='drive']" is necessary)

Thanks! 
Finanlly I find this one is also OK with findall:
"./devices//target[@bus='scsi']/../address[@type='drive']"

Oh, turns out if you do this, you need to use 'tree.xpath' instead of 'tree.findall' [1]. Also, that xpath expression can be simplified further:

  ./devices/disk[target/@bus='scsi']/address[@type='drive']

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/a/6231045

This isn't the same thing. It could return devices that are non-disks but use the SCSI bus. Maybe the 'address[@type="drive"]' piece would prevent that but I'm not sure. Any reason _not_ to use 'xpath' instead? It seems clearer to me, at least
yes np, changing to xpath with the one you referred make more sense.

The tests are failing because we're trying to attach a SCSI volume when there are no SCSI-based volumes currently attached, meaning 'ret' is empty and therefore no max can be found. We probably want to rename this function to something like '_get_scsi_controller_next_unit' and change this line to e.g.:

  return max(ret) + 1 if ret else 0

Then you'd stop doing the '+ 1' wherever this is called.
Done
ok so before it would have counted all the disks on any bus

and now we only look at the scsi bus.
this is the main change.

ya that makes sense
Yes sure

and here you are just folding in the increment logic hence the name change to next instead of max which could be confused with the max capasity rather then the current max in use. this also make sense.
Yes definitely

nit

    ret = [0]

Allowing you to remove the if ret else 0 below.

tempest/lib/services/compute/servers_cli.message: I see, sorry, I misread and thought the problem is loading byte content, not validation.
jsonschema.validate expects a string input, and if body is not empty, it will be changed to string by json.loads(body), but if body is empty, it will remain the type of bytes(b '').
The change make sense, but we can also use  something like this here as we use oslo_Serialization so : oslo_serialization.base64.decode_as_text(encoded, encoding='utf-8')

Could be lightweighted a bit like this:

```
healthcheck_cmd = None
if container_runtime_module == docker:
	# TODO add docker method here
        return healthcheck_cmd

try:
    config_data = container_obj.data['labels']['config_data']
except Exception:
    return healthcheck_cmd

if re.search('healthcheck', config_data):
    healthcheck_line = [elm for elm in config_data.split(',')
                        if re.search('health', elm)]
    healthcheck_cmd = healthcheck_line[0].split(':')[2].strip(
        '}').strip().strip('"')

return healthcheck_cmd
```

Also I wondering if `config_data` contains json, isn't?

In this case you could use the json module to retrieve your cmd.

NIT: You could use below form for debugging messages:

 LOG.debug(f'something happened: {ppm}')

To have debugging messages printed out to log files you can set to true below options in 'tobiko.conf' file:

 [DEFAULT]
 debug = true

Messages produced during a single test case execution are saved into file test_results_*.log

When you run test cases manually via tox you can find test results in below folder:

 $ tox -e <envname>
 $ ls report/<envname>/
 test_results.html	test_results.subunit
 test_results.log	test_results.xml

'test_results.log will contain your log messages separated by test case

/COMMIT_MSG.message: unicode might be better
you are also changing the schema of flavor extra_specs, should also mention here.
Thank you,i will mention it
To be clear, this is supporting unicode in metadata *keys*.  It's already supported in the *values*.

...to also allow unicode in the keys.  (be specific)

But I would suggest making this commit message read less like it's doing two separate things, as that's usually a red flag to reviewers.  (I had to go through the review thoroughly to convince myself that the extra_specs part shouldn't be split into a separate change set.)  For example:

 Allow unicode keys for metadata and extra_specs

 Fix the metadata regex to allow unicode characters in keys
 for instance and image metadata and flavor extra_specs.
Thank you very much,i will accept your suggest.

nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/flavo.message: Jay pointed out that this is redundant (it's already covered by the {1,255} part of the regex).

...but I now see you carried this over from the original metadata key pattern, which is the right thing to do (even though it's redundant there as well) because you could get different schema failure messages, and theoretically somebody might be relying on that.
I'm scratching my head on this one... why again don't we just want to use metakey_pattern for flavor extra spec keys?

nova/api/validation/parameter_types.py.message:
if you use r'' (raw string) here, you can avoid doubling the backslashes twice.

 metakey_pattern = r'^[\\a-zA-Z0-9-_:. ]{1,255}$'
can you give some comments at least? because 4e00-u9fa is something not every one knows... for chinese characters only?
that's my understanding, you want to support all languages
Thanks for reply. Not only chinese characters need to support. Other non-english languages also need to support. I have modified the regex. Please take a look. Thanks again.

I am not expert in this area :(
quick search on regex for %s seems not match existing pattern
is this %s equal to 'any char'?

then it means anything? why we need a %s here...
just a string with 1-255 should be fine?

I think you're just getting confused because we're building the regex in two steps.  metakey_pattern_base isn't being sent to the regex engine - we're using it to compose the regex that is. Maybe this helps:

 In [3]: import re

 In [4]: pat_fmt = '^[%s]{1,255}$'

 In [5]: pat = pat_fmt % 'a-zA-Z0-9'

 In [6]: pat
 Out[6]: '^[a-zA-Z0-9]{1,255}$'

 In [7]: re.match(pat, "Hello123")
 Out[7]: <_sre.SRE_Match at 0x7f205c00f510>

 In [8]: re.match(pat, "Hello, world!")

 In [9]:
It's being used as a normal string substitution placeholder, swapped out on the subsequent line with the result of _build_regex_range()

It's because you're mocking ServerMetadataController.create to return the exact value you're checking for, and then calling that mock.  You can make anything pass that way :)

You're going to need something that actually hits the JSON schema validation.
I suspect this isn't a real test of your use case.  I think you want to use an actual unicode string (u"...").  At which point I'm actually not sure whether your fix will work at all...
This test passes without the fix.
self.controller.create is mocked. It does not make sense.

What if the first physical_router has the CRB role and the second has ERB role. Does the first physical_router has the higher priority than others?
We're assuming here that all physical routers has exactly one routing type as pointed in docstring. We could pick random PR in order to detect routing type.

In that case I think find_routing_type can accept a list of physical_routers. We don't need to create a var for single physical_router and it would point up that found routing type was based on all of physical routers.
Those are only two conditions, `and` would do.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ku.message: nit: I see you were trying to keep these alphabetized, (which helps when we enable that pep8 check) but this one is one-off.

From: https://docs.python.org/2/library/site.html

A path configuration file is a file whose name has the form name.pth

deactivate_plugins() here appears to affect the merged overrides at /opt/platform/helm  (i.e. the overrides didnt appear to have the system helm overrides, perhaps this could be because I patched this onto a more recent baseline; however, removing this deactivate_plugins() appeared to workaround it).

There appears to be a pattern where we want to activeate, do stuff, deactivate.  However there are multiple ways the code can break out before the de-activate.  If we need to guarantee those actions are book-ended, we could try using a decorator or a 'with' (ie: enter/exit)

To decouple container application with platform, we should remove such app specific action in sysinv-conductor. Prefer for every app or manifest operator, add function like onPreApply(), onPostApply, in such function create app specific resource.

Other places pair up the activate with de-activate.
This block can raise an exception and therefore never call deactivate.  I assume that is acceptable.
I expect if the apply fails, a reapply would be required which will activate again or remove which would deactivate.
Looks like when we drop python2.7 you can drop this workaround as well

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/helm.py.message: How often is this function called? Might be nice to have an info log if it is only called once when the conductor starts up.

It's called on upload, applies, and updates. Originally, I had it as an info message and thought that for apps with a lot of plugins it sort of polluted the log and didn't provide a whole lot of value. The key info (project/location) can be seen from the armada plugin logging and is only shown once.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: nit: suggest ... 'is enhanced with a semantic check to prevent updating images on a disabled host'.
Done
nit: suggest ... 'check_lock_worker' semantic check is enhanced to prevent ...
Done
nit: suggest ... 'check_swact' semantic check is enhanced to prevent ...
Done

I think this should actually be when *any* host is in the process of updating device images.  (Which would be the same for AIO.)

Ultimately we should be able to remove this restriction if we can get the RPC messaging protocols reliable enough...this would be good if we want to use device image update on large clusters.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message:
Why is this 'reboot_needed' field added ?
It is not used by this update.
This field was added in the previous commit, but was not exposed in the api. It will be used by the conductor in subsequent updates.

enabled ; the check below is correctly looking at operational state of enabled.

I don't think there is a restriction over availability status ; i.e. host can be degraded.

Sorry, didn't consider this in my first round of comments.

Should this check need to prevent swacting when 'either' controller is being updated ? Meaning swacting to or away from a controller that is being updated.

I'm not sure what the requirement is.
Changed to check both controllers for in-progress update.

There shouldn't be anything special about whether it's the controllers or a standalone worker node doing the device image update...any problems would be the same either way.   So the only way this makes sense is if we block swact while *any* node is doing a device image update, not just the controllers.

You are not making use of force_swact 
Would we ever want to bypass this semanitic check using the --force option?
Modified to bypass check with force option

I kind of think that the force flag should allow us to bypass the check...if anything goes wrong after that, it's up to the admin to fix it up.

Ideally we should be able to deal with a swact, since it could also happen due to uncontrolled circumstances.
We said we were going to support the "force" option to allow locking a node that was in the middle of a device image update.
The force option is checked on line 6036 and exit function. So this check would not be executed if force option is specified.
nit: don't care much for the log string. 'device image update swact check bypassed with force option" ?
Yep, I agree that would be clearer.

playbooks/roles/install-apt-repo/tasks/m.message: I'm surprised this is working, I thought apt expected the .gpg extension on GnuPG's native binary format exports and .asc for ASCII-armored copies. Local testing on my Debian/Sid workstation indicates that when I move my personal ASCII-armored repo key from .asc to .gpg then `apt update` it complains "The key(s) in the keyring /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/fungi-yuggoth-org.gpg are ignored as the file has an unsupported filetype."
In fact, it's required to work, using .asc here fails (see earlier PS).  Apparently apt-key will take AA input and write out a binary .gpg file.

Oh! I missed this was going through the apt-key command instead of installing the file directly. We could probably just install the file directly? Or is this the workaround for Xenial lacking .asc file support in /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/ ? Anyway, yes this makes sense. Thanks for clarifying.
Yep, this should work in all distros.  Later we can simplify.

nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py.message:
nit

if (dom_state[0] == libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_SHUTOFF and
    dom_state[1] == libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_SHUTOFF_CRASHED):

tempest/lib/api_schema/response/volume/e.message:
These should be datetime:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#id51

As you can see in examples, they are all iso-8601 formatted.

That is: [parameter_types.datetime, 'null']

(I'm just winging what the right parameter_types is, but you know what I mean).
Response body can be empty, so no required fields.
No required field. But we can add a comment here

this is limited to 255, so can we add - 
'minLength': 0,'maxLength': 255

I do not believe doc :) so always check code.

in API request scheme it is limited to 255 [1] and that is what returned in POST response[2]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/7bb05f327aa207573246f8ab356e2565c7c805b0/cinder/api/schemas/volume_type_encryption.py#L29

[2]  https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/7bb05f327aa207573246f8ab356e2565c7c805b0/cinder/api/contrib/volume_type_encryption.py#L110

I seem don't see this limitation in 
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#create-an-encryption-type,
do I miss something?

Yes I see the length limit in the code.
And it seems we haven't add length limit check for too many fields, like server name, flavor name, keypair name, and so on. So maybe we can leave this for the future?
ditto. it is mandatory in request schema which is returned in the response (above link).

Yes now I'm sure it's mandatory.
And I think we should setup schema check according to api-ref, so I put https://review.opendev.org/677862 to fix the cinder api-ref:)
ditto. it just update the presented value and 'provider' does not seems as mandatory.
ah i misread that in code. cinder adds 'volume_type_id', 'encryption_id' in response always even not present in requst but 'provider' can be missing is not in request.

'volume_type_id', 'encryption_id', 'provider' are mandatory in api ref?
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#volume-types-types

And the cinder code shows that they are not required in request?
this is also listed as optional - https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=list-all-back-end-storage-pools-detail,create-an-encryption-type-detail#volume-types-types

how about volume_type_id and encrypton_id as mentioned in https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=list-all-back-end-storage-pools-detail,create-an-encryption-type-detail,update-an-encryption-type-detail#volume-types-types
yeah, they are part of path.
volume_type_id and encryption_id seems to be only the fields of request?
this does not seems to be required, commented in previous PS comment
